I worked for Bucyrus Erie (one of the greatest mining companies in the world, now gone, bought by CAT). I was fortunate enough per my job to go to mine sites. The first time I witnessed a site blast was in Beckley West Virgina at the Independence Coal Mine, which was both a surface and pit mine (above and below earth). I was about a mile away, up on the ridge watching. I was leaning on a crawler assembly of a several million-pound machine. I could see the smoke from the infancy of the blasting cap charges... then the earth began to lift sequentially (area was about the size of a football field) from my vantage point. About 1-1.5 seconds I felt the earth rumble/move the machine I was leaning against, then several seconds later the sound... somewhere in that time was a mix of the air concussion waves... I was like a 12yrs old boy and was in AWE!!! This reminded me of that memory. I really needed to get myself down to a launch and witness it first hand... thanks for sharing.

Without reading the comments, I wanted to make my own.
I don't remember who makes it, but I think the helicopter overhead was a Ranger. Isn't that Bell Aviation (not sure of spelling)?
Also, I heard the 2x3 booms with the echos. It's amazing to think that, with sufficient processing and enhancement, you could actually get a thorough sonic picture of the area simply due to the volume and type of the sounds you found?
I love this kind of thing, particularly as a visually impaired person. Binaural audio is a wonderful way for me to explore the world, and it's one of the few technologies that nobody had to advocate for. It's good for everyone.
As a note, I haven't used phones from other companies for this, but the stereo recording capacity of the newer iPhones generates near-binaural audio files, but the compression the phone automatically adds somewhat ruins the effect with louder noises (which means something like a car door, not a rocket launch).
Good to know that fantastic audio is available to the masses.

One of the best ways I have hear a sonic boom explained, it is all the sound whatever the object is making played all at once as the shock cone.   That is why you never hear the sonic boom when it is leaving because you are inside the cone. But when they renter you get the sound of reentry all at once, the sonic booms, then the sound of the rocket motors since you are now inside the sonic cone.  Still really cool to hear.

I was there with my lovely spouse watching from the waterfront near the SpaceX launch and landing control center. Sunburned and happy.
My sisters and I watched Apollo 11 launch from the pool at Rockledge High School across the river, where we had swimming lessons that day.
The spouse and I were back for SpaceX Demo-2 in May, this time with our two adult children, traveling from TN during the pandemic - the last time I could visit with my aunt in Rockledge before she contracted COVID19 and died in July.
Launches never get old - each one is it’s own technology miracle of science and cooperation. I wish you (and my family) could have experienced the Apollo launches (with less efficient engines and sound dampening) - they shook the earth for miles, like a small earthquake.

It took about 12.73 seconds to hear the sound from the launch site. That means the rocket was about 4.4 km away if the temperature outside was 20 degrees Celcius.  Just thought I would flex on my high school physics knowledge.

This is my guess: the echos are the sound hitting the ground and coming  back up to the microphone as a reflection. The greater distance that the reflection travels to the microphone in relation to the sound directly from the boosters to the microphone creates a time delay, resulting in the echo phenomenon. There are two additional echoes visible on the waveform that are for some reason less in amplitude and therefore not audible—hence the perceived ten booms.

We moved to Melbourne, Florida ( about 40 miles south of Kennedy Space Center ) back in 1969.......and let me tell ya, the sight & sound of this Falcon Heavy is NOTHING compared to those gigantic Saturn V rocket launches during the Apollo missions. Known as "the F1 Saturn V engine"........they EACH produced 1.5 MILLION lbs of thrust, and there were FIVE of them used on each Saturn V rocket, the biggest & most powerful rocket ever launched by NASA. Just 1 of those F1 Saturn V engines is 18 feet tall and produces the same amount of thrust as ALL 3 engines on the space shuttle combined. I was between 7 & 8 yrs old when Dad had a friend who knew a man that got us VIP passes to get closer than any other civilians were allowed to witness the Apollo launches. I swear, as the rocket was lifting off, the thrust was so great, you would be standing in place on concrete or asphalt, yet you would look down & see your feet literally moving around as you stood still from the intense vibrations caused by 7.5 million lbs of thrust.  Now THAT was a sensation like no other. Words can't properly convey the experience. No other launches caused that to happen........not even the space shuttle missions. The Saturn V rockets produced 5 TIMES the thrust compared to the space shuttle. I still live here in Melbourne.........after all these years.

Simply awesome, almost feels like being there! As a child I actually lived in Titusville when the shuttle program was still active, maybe a 10 minute drive to Cape Canaveral, and we use to step outside the classroom to watch the shuttle launches, and it was epic every time! Was very inspiring as a kid, and I'm so glad we had teachers that were willing to get us out to witness the launches. As I got older and started working, I worked at an auto parts store and you could literally see the VAB through the front door glass across US1 and the river, we were that close. The re-entry sonic booms when the shuttle landed were unlike anything else, and it's extremely hard to describe it to anyone that has never witnessed or felt it before. I want to make it back down there again to witness a Falcon Heavy launch though. Those booster landings look and sound simply breathtaking through a camera lens, but knowing how the shuttle launches were in person, I know I'm missing so much more!

I was just out of basic training in the AF when I got stationed at Patrick AFB and worked at the Cape out of Hanger C near the light house. I toured the VAB building and it was at the time in 67’ the largest building in the world by volume. They had to build a 10 story building for air conditioning as it would cloud up and rain inside. They could assemble four Sat V rockets at the same time. If I remember right the VAB out to the pads is two miles. Saw the Crawler in use for the Saturn V. How they made the roadbed for the crawler is a video in itself. Hanger C is 6 miles south from the launch pad where the first unmanned Saturn V launched in Nov 67’. The noise and vibrations broke a few windows and cracked several more. I will never forget that launch.  Don’t know how it compared to the Falcon Heavy but it took much longer to clear the gantry. Walter Cronkite was broadcasting from the press area in a trailer and he said the roof was coming down on him. They moved the press area back another mile after that. I think there may be a video on YouTube. It was the Saturn V launch of Apollo IV.

If I could make a suggestion, you should bleed about 1%-4% of each ear into the opposite ear. Having complete isolation between the left and right ear loses realism. Just because a sound happens on the left doesn't mean your right ear won't hear it. Sounds are also a millisecond or two behind the source side due to reflection. Try it out and let me know what you think.

It took about 12.73 seconds to hear the sound from the launch site. That means the rocket was about 4.4 km away if the temperature outside was 20 degrees Celcius. Just thought I would flex on my high school physics knowledge.

Edit: I just want to clarify a few things. In no way was I trying to be a showoff. "Flexing on my high school physics knowledge" was literally a joke and people can't seem to understand sarcasm anymore. I know it's simple multiplication that you learn in grade 3. I know you can get the numbers on google. I remembered the speed of sound from high school and thought people would find it interesting how far the rocket was based solely on how long it took to hear it.

It took the sound 19.20 seconds to reach you. The speed of sound travels at v= 340m/s

Distance from the rocket was 19.20s x 340m = 6.5 Km

Distance from the two rocket boosters: It took approx 25.5s - 26 seconds for the sound to reach you
V = 340 m/s
So V multiplied by T = 340m/s x 26s = 8840 or about 9 Km. Answer is a bit unclear as to the fact Im not sure exactly when the rocket boosters started and I might have started recording after the initiation of the booster rockets. Anyhow its close enough.

I guess, that it's not that interesting to anybody, but I just wanted to thank you, Destin, very, very much, for all of your amazing videos. Not only am I fascinated by your content, to experience your sound traveler series is something very special for me. I lost almost a big part of my left ear's function, and the right one is damaged, too, because of a medical condition when I was a teen, and with the hearing, I lost the ability to pinpoint the direction a sound comes from.
Watching and listening to these videos I can put my fingertips onto my headphones, and feel the direction (at least left / right). I wished there would be a device for my everyday life that would make this possible, or something like an app, that could show my position and a sound's source on a 360° ring around me. Well. Someday, maybe. :)

The Sound. My BIL was a Missle Maintenance Mechanic at Minot AFB N.D. He took me into a Minuteman III silo to look at all that was in there. The missile itself is underwhelming. My BIL was constantly reminded that anytime the crew was within 1/4 mile of a live missile, it could be sent without warning, and the sound pressure alone would kill a human being. He was privileged to witness a test firing of a live missile and told me he was utterly convinced this was correct.

at 6:20 approx, the boosters have turned on their grid fans so that's the third sonic boom and we can actually hear the third sonic boom at 6:48 approx, by this you can actually calculate the distance of the photographer's location from the rocket landing position. D=V*T, 343(speed of sounds in m/s) multiplied by 28. This guys were atleast 9600 meters away or 9.6 km away. Jesus physics is cool af.
Can you try to sync the audio to the visual events too?
fire on boosters 6:13, sonic booms 6:48 => 35 seconds (without speed of light in calculations) ==> 35 (s) * 345 (m/s) = 12075 m = 12 km from where the boosters landed

I'm back to watch this video for the 100th time and for some reason, even though I'm almost positive you won't have time to respond to a comment on a video that is 7 months old, I've decided today is the day to ask a question I've had since the first time I saw this. The binaural audio definitely gives you the feeling that you are actually there, but so does the video. I'm having trouble figuring out what  makes this video, and many other bystander videos, seem more realistic than the SpaceX footage? Even though the SpaceX footage is fantastic, it doesn't have the "seeing it with your own eyes" feel like this video does. At first I thought it was distance at which it was recorded. You can see more of the terrain and buildings which help put the size and speed of the rocket into perspective, but the video still looks more realistic when that's all out of frame and there is only the blue sky as the background. I keep going back and forth between the two videos, but I just can't put my finger on what makes them look so different. Any thoughts?

Even without the grid fins, legs, and engines igniting, the rocket structure itself will have it's own sonic boom. These booms were always heard by the crews of the Freedom Star and Liberty Star. These two ships were the recovery vessels out at sea. They recovered the SRB's during the shuttle launches. Each one of those SRB's had it's own sonic boom.

What's so hard about turning an existing camera 108* (to make it point up into space instead of down) and filming an entire rocket launch sequence from lift off to docking with the ISS  unedited and with no breaks in continuity? People want to see a rocket entering space and docking. They also want to see the transfer through the airlock on the ISS. Speaking of airlocks, submarines have airlocks between every compartment, why are there none on the ISS? If a tiny piece of space debris puts a hole in the ISS everyone inside would instantly die from the near infinite vacuum of space. Not even spacesuits in every compartment to give them half a chance. Not sure I believe the ISS is in space.  Funny, sonic booms have never been heard during any NASA rocket launches, in fact people questioned the lack a few years back. For the launch portion of this video I wanted to sync, or at least come close to syncing the video with the sound of the boosters. I copied the URL into a new window and ran the video on two screens. I turned the sound off on the one I'm watching. I estimated (observed) about 15-16 seconds delay, due to the distance from the launch pad so I started the window with the audio first and cued up the visual window to moment of ignition, then the sound looked to be pretty well in sync with the video. The two videos are the same. that footage was taken from the live version of the launch where they had a few directorial issues. the biggest and most noticable part of those problems were that when the fairing deployed the original live feed showed core stage projectile info rather than starman popping out of his fairing. However, you can tell the two pictures you have used were from the same rocket in a few different steps. At 5:01 you see the re entry burn on the bottom of the screen. on both the screens you can see a small glow start just to the centre right of the two screens. The rockets were actually about 15 seconds out of sync. this was because spacex wasn't sure if the radio singals would cross between the two boosters on landing. You can see this in the burns that one booster ignites slightly before the other. the second and most important piece evidence that these two videos are from the same rocket is the landing zone as seen in the landing burn. in the video at 5:18 you only see lz1. lz2 is black with a white x.

Were those boosters really (according to my rough calculations) roughly 11.66km away from the cameras? But google maps measurement shows 15.19km away. What am I doing wrong with the calculation? Speed of sound is 343m/s. So if it takes roughly 34 seconds before seeing the engines come on, and hearing the sonic booms, my calculations are 11.66km. (343x34)
But maps show 15.19km.
However 15.19km divided by 343 is 44.3 seconds. Which is exactly the time it takes for the engine sound (as soon as it lights up) of those boosters to get to the cameras. And NOT the sonic booms, just the engine sound.

And according to SpaceX the first sonic boom comes from the engine. And clearly you see those engines light on. But the sonic booms come way too early.

You mentioned that the two feeds coming form the two boosters "looked identical"; they actually were. They were the same feed. There were several telling features, most notably the fact that "both" videos showed flame from the "other" booster at the top of the screen, while approaching what looked like identical landing pads, but if both cameras were facing towards each other, the road approaching the landing pad would have been on the other side of the pad in one of the videos. In other words, the landing pad you can see is not rotationally symmetrical, so the images would not have looked identical to each other. But the biggest smoking gun is that if you watch the replay video: https://youtu.be/wbSwFU6tY1c?t=24m43s you can see that the two booster feeds are now strikingly different, and the video panels are larger than they were in the live stream. In fact, they actually partially obscure the third stream from the second stage. This is because they were retrospectively added to the video to fix the mistake.

I like your videos but as far as this one I have to be honest. The first manned space flight was by Russia the 12th of April 1961. It's now 2018 and were still using pretty much the same technology and relatively the same craft. 57 years later and cars have drastically changed, life has drastically changed, computers have drastically changed, the internet exists and now we have the F117, B1 Bomber's and what not... and we are still stuck back in 1961 with our space industry. Sure it carries more and computers allow it to land in a new way, but that's it?! No better space craft? No better means of propulsion? The first settlers sailed across the Atlantic on the Mayflower which was little more than an oversized rowboat! Columbus before that sailed August 3rd, 1492 and was at sea a solid two months before landing in the Bahamas on San Salvador. And we can barely limp to the moon with all our modern advancement. I love space and space exploration but sorry Mr. Musk, I need something more than a bigger rocket with a bigger payload to make me take notice. Feel free to shout me down and I'm sure I've rained on someone's parade but honestly, look at the whole picture and please don't tell me that thanks to our space program we now have Velcro and Tupperware and hope I pop a champagne. Our space advancement is horribly depressing. Regardless though, I like your videos.

Binaural recording is a crock. It doesn’t work, if it does for you it’s just a self delusion.
There is also not credible explanation for how it works... because it doesn’t.
Human hearing is totally unresponsive to shifts in phase between left and right which is the only possible way of getting 3D information from a 2D system.
Do some actual research into this (I worked on this stuff researching NICAM compression systems for the ABC design and development labs in the late 80s so I know first hand) and you will actually be smarter than you were yesterday.

I experienced this firsthand in the late 1980s. Went to the Cape on a press pass for a shuttle launch, STS43 or STS53 (don't remember which). The mission was to capture a satellite already in orbit and bring it back to earth for repairs.  We watched from the press bleachers which are about 5 miles from the pad.  The sound of the solid boosters is a series of physical shock waves, probably below 20Hz, that I felt as much as heard.  Imagine continuous rolling thunder in a mountain holler, and you've got some idea. Both incredible and unforgettable!

Hey Destin, just a quick question: In between stars there are about 3 atoms each cm³ on average, between the planets of our solar system probably a little more (well that's what a quick Google search taught me at least). Of course in the proximity of the earth there are more atoms, but still quite few compared to something that can be called an "atmosphere". With all the rockets that launched and are about to launch from earth, what about the combustion products that are blasted into the almost empty vacuum of space? I could imagine due to the big difference in preasure of areas behind the rocket (filled with the atoms that are "thrown" out of a space crafts engine to push it forward) and the surrounding "space" these atoms try to evenly distribute over a large volume until gravity effects of planets and stars disturb the perfectly even distribution of matter that is desired by entropy. Still as an rough estimate with upcoming space travel to mars on a regular basis won't that "fill" the space between the solar systems planets with matter that is not supposed to be there in the first place? What about this material? Will it be sucked up be the gravity forces of planets and become part of them? Or will it locally increase the amount of atoms per cm³ and hence create a drag on the planets slowing them down on their orbit around sun? I know space is huge and it won't fill up just like that but with a theoretical vast increase of space travel and with the time in mind the material needs to evenly distribute into outer space I wonder if this very tiny effect can be measureable or even have real life implications on our solar system? Also in case the exhaust products are sucked up by planets, when we land on these planets in the future and analyze the material composition that we find, how do we know it is not polluted by out space travel residues? Just thinking ..... Hope you understand my question (: That's the best english I can do ^^ ...

I heard 3 and 3 sonic booms with some "echo" in between them. I would not say it was 10 booms. The explanation is very nice, but my brain automatically filtered out the sounds that were clearly not "booms". I wonder if the building might have something to do with it. Maybe the "echo" was sound reflected from the ground and it took longer to reach the roof. Since I have designed passive crossovers for speakers (not professionaly), I know that sound reflections off the ground can interfere with measurment, as both driver and microphone are a certain height above it (in this case the sonic booms and the rooftop are somewhat higher above the ground, which looks nice and flat. There is a reason why there is a weird floor in an anechoic chamber. Did anybody on the ground in a similar distance from the landing pads experience something similar? Can you please write it here? An amateur video of the landings (such as this one /watch?v=otfBviE1G3k) show the back burns were nowhere near as synchronized as it seems from these feeds (as they should have been, as they intentionally created some separation between the two boosters to make it easier for the field radars to track them). Even if they didn't do it on purpose, there would still be some variations as each booster has slightly different physical characteristics (e.g. mass, drag, moments of inertia) as well as slightly different environmental conditions.

YES! I was looking for something like this. First off, I've been to the VAB and I think the glimpse in this video is the only thing that has ever come close to describing its size. Second, from the chemistry side of things, you can tell it's a LOX/RP1 rocket by the faint soot trail. The shuttle leaves behind a lot of Al2O3/AlCl3 from the APCP that fuels the boosters, leaving a large plume of smoke. The LOX/LH2 main engines leave behind only water which isn't dispersed by CO2 like it is in the LOX/RP1 engines, hence the Falcon 9 and the heavy variant leave basically no trail.

Just to put it out there, it WAS only 1 of the boosters videos on the two different boxes on the SpaceX feed. They just simply made a mistake. If you notice, when it was launched, the image on both boxes was identical. If it were from two different boosters, the video would look different because the one on the right wouldn't be able to see exactly what the one of the left saw. Instead, it was the exact same image mirrored all the way up.

Another example where you can tell it was the same one was when they were coming back down. If you notice, as it gets closer and closer to the "pads", you will see the second pad in the corner of the box going by in the original feed (not this particular video because it wasn't the whole thing). You will also notice that one of the pads had blue paint on it and the other was white. In the video, you clearly see that "both" boosters were landing on the one that was white, but then it cuts out to the side view of both pads and you will see the one in the foreground was the one with the blue on it. So, like I said, they kinda messed up on that and just mirrored one boosters video on both boxes.

Just an observation I made while watching it. I'm sure I'll get flamed for it even though I shouldn't.

Hey Destin, as much as I would like the two feeds to have been of each returning booster, if you look a little closer you'll see that both screens are in fact only showing the return of one booster. There is a slight lag which at first makes it appear to be different boosters, but near the end you'll see they both end up on the same landing pad which doesn't make sense. Also the stabilizing thrusts would be reactive to the environment and not really pre-programmed all that much. Just my two cents, great vids!!

Also in the syncronised landing, look at the X marking on the pad. Earlier in the live feed a view of the pads clearly showed quite different markings on the pads. Those two shots are the same, just slightly separated in time, probably by video coding delays. But there's no question that they both landed fine. There's lots of good shots of both of them landing together, and lots of eye witnesses. Still very impressive.

The two booster feeds were NOT from separate boosters. I know that's what the announcers said, but they were clearly incorrect. The two feeds were actually from a stereoscopic pair of cameras on a single booster. You can tell this for a number of reasons. First, both showed the connection to the central core in the same orientation  with identical backgrounds. Second, both show the re-entry burn from the other booster at the top of the frame with identical backgrounds. Lastly, both show the booster landing on the same pad right at the end. If you re-watch the footage and cross your eyes, you can watch the booster feed in 3D!

Binoural technologies is an amazing thing. There is an Audio brand called BACCH, Theoretica Applied Physics. This "stereo image purifier" is developed in princeton university. With the Bacch you can get this kind of experience with stereo speakers. Even if you have the two speakers in front of you, the sound come from the side and place every sound exactly where it should be. So if you listen to a concert you will get all the instruments exactly where they are in real life when they where recorded.

Hey Destin. I too enjoyed to launch and landing of the falcon heavy. But i i disagree with your statement that the two lower camera angles shown are from each booster. i do believe the images they showed are mirrored from booster #2. Why do i think that? well, for one, in the separation shot, both boosters show the same coastline down below. doesnt make sense, if one booster sits left, one is right, each should show a different coastline, right? Next thing, the separation, in both angles the booster tips the same direction, and shows the core in the exact same location on screen. Shouldnt it be left and right (mirrored) like a left and right booster seperated? Next thing, the boosters landing delayed, first #1, than #2. in both images, you can see booster #1 (fire and exausttrail from the engine). Booster #1 lands on a dark pad with white SpaceX marking, #2 landed on a white pad with dark spacex marking. in both captures you see it landing on the white with dark markings, landing. I do agree a lot of engineering went into the guidance system, but both boosters landing at the exact same rotational angle? Mirrorlike landing, both boosters experienced the exact same wind conditions? not a single wiff different to another? doubtful.

Again, not saying anything negative, but i think i have some valid points to back up my claim that the videofeed shown from the boosters is in fact mirrored from #2 to #1.

Ya wanna talk about "getting the sensation" for both sight and sound........NOTHING NASA has today compares to the sheer sight & sound of the following. ( NOTE: I'm not talking about "technology" and "ability".......merely the raw sight & sound. ) We moved to Melbourne, Florida in early 1969 when I was 7 years old. We were only a 20 minute drive from the launch pads. From that point onward, we drove to EVERY Apollo launch & got as close as any civilian was legally allowed to be, and during 2 of those launches, even closer. My Dad had a friend who got us into an area even closer, due to his clearances. The sight & sound.....PLUS >>> THE FEELING of those HUGE Saturn V rockets dwarfed even the space shuttles. ( I've watched nearly all of the shuttles LIVE & in person too. ) During lift-off of those Saturn V rocket engines, the largest ever made & used by NASA in their entire history.......we were standing on either a concrete slab, or asphalt, depending on which mission was being launched, and I'm not kidding, standing in one spot, in addition to the incredible sight, sound, AND FEELING, you could look down at your shoes, and literally SEE YOUR FEET SLIGHTLY MOVING, DUE TO THE INTENSE VIBRATION CAUSED BY THE INCREDIBLE THRUST. No kidding, the ground was vibrating so intensely, we were actually moving around ever so slightly, but enough that we could clearly see that our feet were moving on the ground!!!  As spectacular as the space shuttle launches were, they were no match in comparing to those huge Saturn V rockets of the Apollo missions, due to having far more thrust needed to lift such a heavier payload. I still live here in Melbourne, having lived in a number of different homes throughout the years as a kid and adult. No matter where I've lived here, simply climbing up on the roof gives you "a front row seat" for any launch. After watching every Saturn V rocket by the time we moved down here, it only took a couple shuttle launches later on, to realize they weren't nearly as dramatic "up close" ( we were spoiled by the Apollo missions )........so we simply used our roof for any other shuttle launches........and even wherever we happened to be during several launches throughout the entire area of Brevard county ( due to work or school ). No words can describe how awesome it was to witness those Saturn V rockets during launch, and I will never forget them. The shuttles were great too, just not as dramatic. And then........after seeing the very last space shuttle to be "piggy backed" on the top of a jumbo jet back to the Cape here, which was an awesome sight in itself to witness in person........watching all other launches since are "rather boring".......for me anyway.

The sound of the rocket launching is cool and so are the sonic booms, but how come it’s so hard to record or reproduce with high definition what the sound of a rocket launching or a jet in full afterburner really sounds like live? For example, when you hear a fighter jet taking off in afterburner live it has an incredible shearing, ripping sound to it like it’s literally ripping the air apart, yet when you hear reproduced audio of the same event, it most often has a much more “popping” sound to it similar to what you hear during the rocket launch in this video.

I’ve never heard good audio (good from the standpoint of sounding like the original sounds) of either one of those things. It seems like it should be possible, since other audio sounds like music can be reproduced so cleanly and accurately. It would be awesome if you could explain why this is...or better yet find a way to solve this problem!!!

Destin, in regard to the video feeds from the side boosters.   I noticed the synchonized video feeds as well and was initially impressed as you were.  However, watching it again, I realized that it was one video feed on two screens.  The synchronization was just too perfect . . . including the flames from the re-entry burns.  It is at the end when you realize that in both videos the booster is landing at the same pad that it becomes apparent.   Now, LATER, in another video from SpaceX when they have cleaned up the event with some editing, they ACTUALLY DID HAVE TWO DIFFERENT VIDEOS FEEDS from separate boosters and at the end, it is obvious that they are landing on different pads.  However, the initial video from the live coverage was one feed on two screens.

Sitting in my Audio/MIDI production facility, surrounded by 14 speakers and a subwoofer... this was absolutley AMAZING!! I've been lucky enough to be one of the few that got to sign NASA's "Welcome Home Crew of STS-134" sign that hung in the Christopher C. Kraft Jr. Mission Control Center (MCC-H) in Houston, and lucky enough to be a guest Tech Talk speaker at the 2017 New Worlds Cities In Space Conference in Austin Texas; an organization dedicated to deep space travel and future residency. But I've never been lucky enough to be present for these sounds. In fact, while working on a documentary TV program near Cape Canaveral, Florida, I missed the launch of STS-132 by 3 days, delayed by an encroaching hurricane that fizzled out. Thank you Destin for the next best thing! And trust me, I pushed the volume on my studio monitors ALMOST to the point of giving off the "secret white smoke". Here's to being present at one of these launchings!

The two videos of the returning boosters are not of both. They are of one booster. There are two landing pads. One a black circle with the SpaceX logo and another as a white circle with the SpaceX logo. Watch the landing from the point of view of the two videos at around 5:18 - they are "both" landing on the white pad. Now watch a shot of both cores coming in at 5:20. The one landing on the black pad is closest to the camera, the white pad being farther away.

One of the booster video camera signals didn't make it through so SpaceX duplicated the view. Doesn't detract from the mission success. Just one of those quirks people who have nothing better to do in life than to think they found the answer to some conspiracy in the future will use to say this never really happened.

Destin, you're the man!  That being said, in the spirit of your channel, I must respectfully question your/SpaceX's explanation of the "triple sonic booms."  I say this for two reasons:1)  If you rewatch the SpaceX video of the boosters landing, you'll here them call "boosters transonic," so they're either accelerating or decelerating through Mach 1.  Since they are freefalling and at a low altitude at that point, intuitively I think that the latter would be the case.  I think the terminal velocity for those objects in such dense air would be quite low.2)  The whole reason that shocks form is because the leading edge of the object (in this case, probably the nozzle) are disturbing the flow faster than the flow can communicate the information upstream.  When this happens, there is a large gradient as the flows rapidly decelerates from supersonic to subsonic.  Unless the object is going exceptionally fast and has attached oblique shocks (which doesn't seem to be the case), it will form a normal shock which always has subsonic flow downstream of the shock.  This means that there would be one shock ahead of the nozzle and every part of the booster would be in subsonic flow, which means that individual components (nozzle, fins, legs) would not be causing additional shocks because the flow is already subsonic ahead of the nozzle.  For instance, the space shuttle SRBs created one single sonic boom each as the re-entered, and it was at a much higher altitude in thinner air where they had the ability to free-fall supersonically.  The space shuttle itself, however, created a double sonic boom because of it's much, much higher speed and attached oblique shocks/expansion fans.This could be a chance for another Smarter Every Day episode!Here are my two proposed alternate explanations:1)  They are not, in fact, sonic booms at all, but the explosive charges used to extend the legs.  I have no idea how the leg extension mechanisms work, but that is common practice in such scenarios and 1 explosive extension per leg x 3 legs per booster = 6 booms.2)  The aerodynamics are more complex interactions, combinations of normal shocks and multiple expansion fans over a not-very-aerodynamic-backwards-flying rocket.Thoughts?

So, that's a classic slapback echo return, coming from a building or wall behind you, I would guess?... there should be 12, but the 6th and 12th 'booms' are drowned out by reverberation. But why the pronounced temporal gap after the third impulse/return in the left hand spectrogram? Do you see what I'm talking about?

And actually, looking at the waveform analysis, it looks like the 'return/echo' actually has its own 'return/echo', which is most pronounced after the first two waveforms. See that? I would guess from the building that is in front of you and to your right.
I wonder what the audio bitrate is for a 1080p 60fps youtube video? I can only imagine what the original audio must have sounded like.

Tip: Open video in two different windows, pause one video just as the engine ignites, then hit play again the second you hear the ignition start on the 2nd video. It's about 19 seconds apart. Now you can watch it with the sound matching the launch.

Dustin, the reason the booster footage looks so identical is because it is. They mixed up the video feeds, the left and right screens are the same. You can tell because landing zone 1 and 2 have different color pads, white and black, but the side cam footage only shows them landing on white.

The stream accidentally showed the same footage on both screens. You can tell for certain because at the end they land on the same platform (one is colored in a bit, the other is white). If you watch the video posted on SpaceX's channel it properly shows two different feeds of which they use propulsion to stabilize themselves at different times.

It's unhealthy to overthink past brainfarts. Acknowledge, nay embrace, the curiousness of having erred, despite everything, trusting that others would not have, even though they were likely just as caught up in the moment as you.

We are all blobs of somewhat compromised wetware, but that's partly what makes life fun and it's been the source of many an inspirational discovery or at least a hearty laugh or two.

Don't overplay the mistake. Yes, talk about it: help others to understand how mistakes happen and how we can deceive ourselves; how a chain of mistakes can even be fatal. But if nobody died or got hurt, it's probably not something we should announce we'll dwell on, since, well, stuff happens.

Also, how often do we get to say to ourselves, "hey, I spotted something Destin didn't"? :P

@Destin: It is in STEREO 3D!!!
The two frames of footage from the booster separation, boostback, and reentry are actually from two binocular cameras on the north booster with slightly different parallax.. It's crazy to watch the landing in 3D...really makes it feel like a roller coaster :P If you do a magic-eye on the frames side by side, you'll see that it is in 3D stereo. You can also load it into a Google cardboard/daydream or equivalent to get the experience.

For doubters: Evidence to support this includes: The south booster lands first (and hence, is lower) but you can see it's plume in the upper frame of both feeds at the same time; the landing pads are painted differently, and have asymmetrical roads leading to them - if the footage were indeed from separate boosters, then either: The LZ would appear to be considerably different from each camera (one camera would be rotated 180deg) or the plume would not be visible in one frame (if said camera was NOT rotated 180deg). Also, if you inspect dirt and debris on the transparent shroud covering both cameras throughout the flight, you'll see that it is always exactly the same in both frames, just shifted by a few mm due to the parallax, which would be highly improbable if the cameras were on separate boosters.

Your explanation of the triple sonic boom is incorrect, the guy you got your information from was just speculating and is wrong. More Speculation. Most likely the three booms are one the Bow Shock at the engines, two the grid fins, and last the Wake Shock which appears to come from slightly above the nose cone. If the wrong guy was correct the first two boom would be extremely close together, like the engines and legs are on the vehicle. Any boom created by the legs would most likely have coalesced into the Bow Shock. The third and last boom, the Wake Shock is essentially where the air comes back together behind the vehicle. Exactly like the wake of a speedboat.

I listened to this with top of the line Bose headphones. My observation was that in spite of the use of binaural recording, I didn't feel a sense of live presence.  The technology in no way compares to reality. I think there are a couple of reasons for this - technology and psychology. When we are present in a soundscape in reality, I think our brain discounts some sounds while it favours others. For example, we may pay no attention to things like camera clicks while other sounds, like perhaps a conversation nearby, will take our attention. When listening to an audio track, everything is presented to us unfiltered by our brain and suddenly insignificant sounds like camera clicks tend to dominate the recording. Beyond that, dynamic range limitations change the balance of sounds in the mix. I'm sure peaks of the sound of the rocket blasting off were probably much sharper for the people there than in the recording. Finally, I'm sure they could feel that sound in the pit of their stomachs and we aren't going to get that feeling from headphones. In the end, though I really appreciate the effort made to bring us a state of the art binaural recording, I remained unimpressed.

Hey Destin, I have watched the video of the launch several times now, and I don't think the feed of the "two boosters in perfect sync" it is actually what they say it is. Before separation, when the feed was showing the burn with the boosters attached to the core, the feeds were identical. - they should have been inverted 180 degrees. watch the video again, at T+ 01:45, just before booster engine cutoff for example. Then, at the exact moment of separation T+ 02:33-02:35, the two "screens" on bottom have identical lens flare too. the feeds are a fraction of a second out of sync, but they are coming from the same camera on one booster. the two boosters would have different views of the earth when they reorient as they were turning opposite directions. If you watch very carefully as the boosters return to the landing pad you can see the Other one of the boosters in the frame. you can see its jets, and its burn as it ignites... from around T+ 05:58 you start seeing a tiny jets in the view, and then from T+ 06:35 you actually see the other booster firing to slow it down. Watch the part at T+ 09:12 where the announcers discovered the core booster punched a hole in "Yes I Still Love You" "Oh, we just got confirmation oh umm... yeah... errrrrr " - oops! OOh well, two out of three ain't bad, right?

I only counted 6 sonic booms for some reason. Also, if you watch the launch again and keep an eye on the smoke as the rocket launches from the pad, you can literally see the ripples of sound passing through the smoke!

Destin, if you look closely enough at the booster camera views, they are one view, one camera, duplicated. Someone must have made an error in the feed. We hear the rumble of the launch, 50 miles up the coast, then hear the rumble of the booster landing only minutes later. When there's a cloud layer, it's even louder and longer duration. The sound is very much a part of the feeling of a launch.

+SmarterEveryDay look at the landing site of the 2 boosters and compare that to the shots of the 2 landing sites beforehand. At the start it is shown that the LZ1 has a dark surface with a light ring around, where LZ2 has a lighter colored surface. The camera feed however shows the light colored one on both screens, so that tells you that both were from the booster that returned to LZ2. This might have been a camera operation error where they accidentally showed the same feed twice, but after the booster separation when we got the 4 screen view, we did not see the video feed of the booster that landed on LZ1. It is still a remarkable feat though, that they seperated so cleanly and that they both landed almost at the same time, as seen from the camera on the ground.

Actually, the live feed from the two boosters looked identical because someone messed it up and just duplicated the image. There are three dead giveaways that it's the same footage: 1) a speck of dust diffracting the light on the camera lens in identical position on both views, 2) the landing pad being identical, even though one booster landed on a white landing pad, and the other on a black one, and 3) the boosters did not land at the exact same time, but one landed about a second before the other.

In a video later uploaded by SpaceX you can see the footage from the two boosters and it's quite different.
